column1: an excisable offence and that he had no knowledge. In order to arrive at such a
principle,  the  learned  Magistrate  has  had  recourse  to  a  series  of  judgments
pronounced under Section 40 of the Forest Ordinance. The learned Magistrate,
at page 4 of the order, holds the following:
“ඒ අ(cid:489)ව ෙමම න(cid:397)ෙ(cid:617)ද (cid:648)රාබ(cid:464) ආඥා පනත යටෙ(cid:430) වරද(cid:250) සදහා ෙයාදා ගත වහනය ස(cid:572)බ(cid:486)ධව
ඉ(cid:610)(cid:613)(cid:572)ක(cid:606) (cid:618)(cid:646)(cid:486) (cid:541)ශ්නගත වාහනය  (cid:648)රාබ(cid:464)  වරද(cid:250)  සදහා ෙයාදා  ගැ(cid:488)ම වැළ(cid:250)(cid:619)මට  ගත හැ(cid:251)

(cid:646)ය(cid:613) (cid:539)(cid:601)වාර(cid:250)ෂණ (cid:257)යාමා(cid:601)ග ග(cid:430) බව(cid:430),  තම(cid:486)ෙ(cid:280) දැ(cid:489)ම(cid:251)(cid:486) ෙතාරව  එම වරද (cid:646)(cid:464) කර ඇ(cid:431)
බව(cid:430), සක(cid:597)තා වැ(cid:395)බර සා(cid:250)(cid:639) අ(cid:489)ව අ(cid:477)කරණය හ(cid:575)ෙ(cid:617) තහ(cid:620)(cid:606) කළ (cid:594)(cid:433)ය.”
To  arrive  at  this  conclusion,  the  learned  Magistrate  refers  to  several  case  law
